         <li id="cite_note-111">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-111">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           It is possible to customize all Gedit shortcuts because it is
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gtk" title="Gtk">
            Gtk
           </a>
           based.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-emacs_pico-112">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-emacs_pico_112-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-emacs_pico_112-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           pico uses most of Emacs's motion and deletion commands: ^F ^B ^P ^N ^D etc. See
           <a class="external text" href="http://homepages.math.uic.edu/~diochnos/ta/2008/mcs260/terminal/pico_tutorial.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Pico: A Unix text editor
            </i>
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120905115648/http://homepages.math.uic.edu/~diochnos/ta/2008/mcs260/terminal/pico_tutorial.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            Archived
           </a>
           2012-09-05 at the
           <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
            Wayback Machine
           </a>
           . retrieved 2012-01-09.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-113">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-113">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           GNU Emacs can have Wordstar emulation, with the command M-x wordstar-mode, as found from
           <a class="external text" href="http://web.mit.edu/Emacs/source/emacs/lisp/emulation/ws-mode.el" rel="nofollow">
            ws-mode.el
           </a>
           retrieved 2017-03-14. See also the "Emulation" section of the
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Emulation.html#index-emulating-other-editors-3833" rel="nofollow">
            GNU Emacs manual
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031315/http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Emulation.html" rel="nofollow">
            Archived
           </a>
           2016-03-04 at the
           <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
            Wayback Machine
           </a>
           ..
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-gnu.org-114">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-gnu.org_114-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-gnu.org_114-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-gnu.org_114-2">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               c
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-gnu.org_114-3">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               d
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031315/http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Emulation.html" rel="nofollow">
             "Archived copy"
            </a>
            . Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Emulation.html" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 2016-03-04
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              2016-07-22
             </span>
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Archived+copy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gnu.org%2Fsoftware%2Femacs%2Fmanual%2Fhtml_node%2Femacs%2FEmulation.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AComparison+of+text+editors">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-JedCUAkeys-115">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-JedCUAkeys_115-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           The JED base release comes with a basic CUA emulation, but it doesn't bother to bind lots of useful editor features.  Also, like some other editors, 1 side of a region must be at the cursor.  The main extension collections
           <a class="external text" href="http://jedmodes.sourceforge.net" rel="nofollow">
            jedmodes
           </a>
           /
           <a class="external text" href="https://packages.debian.org/stretch/jed-extra" rel="nofollow">
            jed-extra
           </a>
           and the
           <a class="external text" href="https://gitlab.com/dram/red" rel="nofollow">
            "Red Project"
           </a>
           have improved versions, tackling the former problem in particular.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-116">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-116">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://sourceforge.net/p/joe-editor/mercurial/ci/default/tree/docs/man.md" rel="nofollow">
             "JOE - Joe's Own Editor"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             JOE - Joe's own editor / Mercurial / [2e4f45] /docs/man.md
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              23 October
             </span>
             2015
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             JOE also emulates several other editors. JSTAR is a close imitation of WordStar […]. JPICO is a close imitation of the Pine mailing system's PICO editor […]. JMACS is a GNU-EMACS imitation. […] Key binding tables are defined. You can define as many as you like […].
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=JOE+-+Joe%26%2339%3Bs+own+editor+%2F+Mercurial+%2F+%5B2e4f45%5D+%2Fdocs%2Fman.md&amp;rft.atitle=JOE+-+Joe%27s+Own+Editor&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fsourceforge.net%2Fp%2Fjoe-editor%2Fmercurial%2Fci%2Fdefault%2Ftree%2Fdocs%2Fman.md&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AComparison+of+text+editors">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-117">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-117">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.megalextoria.com/usenet-archive/news046f1/b66/net/sources/00005623.html" rel="nofollow">
             "Usenet - megalextoria"
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Usenet+-+megalextoria&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.megalextoria.com%2Fusenet-archive%2Fnews046f1%2Fb66%2Fnet%2Fsources%2F00005623.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AComparison+of+text+editors">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-kateVi-118">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-kateVi_118-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            Kate
           </i>
           supports an optional
           <a class="external text" href="http://hamberg.no/erlend/2008/11/24/the-vi-input-mode-for-kate-is-done/" rel="nofollow">
            VI Input Mode
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090228202026/http://hamberg.no/erlend/2008/11/24/the-vi-input-mode-for-kate-is-done/" rel="nofollow">
            Archived
           </a>
           2009-02-28 at the
           <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
            Wayback Machine
           </a>
           ..
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-pico_emacskey-119">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-pico_emacskey_119-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-pico_emacskey_119-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           pico (and nano) uses most of Emacs's motion and deletion commands: ^F ^B ^P ^N ^D etc. See
           <a class="external text" href="http://homepages.math.uic.edu/~diochnos/ta/2008/mcs260/terminal/pico_tutorial.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Pico: A Unix text editor
            </i>
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120905115648/http://homepages.math.uic.edu/~diochnos/ta/2008/mcs260/terminal/pico_tutorial.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            Archived
           </a>
           2012-09-05 at the
           <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
            Wayback Machine
           </a>
           . retrieved 2012-01-09.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-120">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-120">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           In
           <i>
            SciTE
           </i>
           , custom keystrokes may be assigned to Lua scripts, external programs or lexers (highlighters).
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-vsbind-121">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-vsbind_121-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            SlickEdit
           </i>
           provides emulation of VisualStudio, Visual C++ 6, CodeWright, Epsilon and ISPF key bindings in addition to those given in the table.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-vsosxbind-122">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-vsosxbind_122-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            SlickEdit
           </i>
           supports CodeWarrior, Xcode and BBEdit key binding emulation.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-vsvimbind-123">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-vsvimbind_123-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            SlickEdit
           </i>
           includes support of vi key bindings, the ex command line and some, but not all Vim extensions.
          </span>
         </li>

         <li id="cite_note-DosOemFont-147">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            <sup>

          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-gnuEmacsUTF8-148">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-gnuEmacsUTF8_148-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            GNU Emacs
           </i>
           : While GNU Emacs supports the UTF-8 encoding, it doesn't fully support the Unicode standard, since it doesn't fully support the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm (see comment in the 'Right-to-left and bidirectional text' section below).
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-gnuEmacsUTF16-149">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-gnuEmacsUTF16_149-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            GNU Emacs
           </i>
           : While GNU Emacs supports the UTF-16 encoding, it doesn't fully support the Unicode standard, since it doesn't fully support the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm (see comment in the 'Right-to-left and bidirectional text' section below).
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Jed_UTF16-150">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Jed_UTF16_150-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            JED
           </i>
           s
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.paneura.com/~dino/wjed.html" rel="nofollow">
            ms-Windows version
           </a>
           comes with a pair of scripts that can convert UTF-16 text files (actually anything iconv can convert) to and from JED's internal UTF-8.  The
           <a class="external text" href="https://gitlab.com/dram/red" rel="nofollow">
            Red Project
           </a>
           releases include an enhanced version of these scripts.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-NoteTab_Unicode-151">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-NoteTab_Unicode_151-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-NoteTab_Unicode_151-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Although
           <i>
            NoteTab
           </i>
           is not a native Unicode editor, you can open, edit, convert, and save such files reliably as long as all the text fits within a single ANSI code page supported by Windows.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-nviUTF8Gentoo-152">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-nviUTF8Gentoo_152-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            nvi
           </i>
           Gentoo
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-153">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-153">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           RText supports EBCDIC n z/OS and anywhere with a JVM that supports it
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-154">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-154">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           SciTE can open files in UTF or one single-byte encoding specified in a configuration file.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Sublime_Unicode-155">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Sublime_Unicode_155-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            Sublime
           </i>
           supports Unicode editor but you can not open and edit some the language. e.g. Bangla, Thai
           <a class="external free" href="https://github.com/SublimeTextIssues/Core/issues/663" rel="nofollow">
            https://github.com/SublimeTextIssues/Core/issues/663
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-TextPad_Unicode-156">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-TextPad_Unicode_156-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-TextPad_Unicode_156-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            TextPad
           </i>
           can load and save UTF-8 and UTF-16 text files, but cannot use or even preserve characters outside of the system encoding.
           <a class="external autonumber" href="http://forums.textpad.com/viewtopic.php?t=4777" rel="nofollow">
            [9]
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-TseIso_8859_1-157">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-TseIso_8859_1_157-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           when choosing e.g. New Courier font
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Vedit_Unicode-158">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-Vedit_Unicode_158-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Vedit_Unicode_158-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            Vedit
           </i>
           can convert UTF-8 and UTF-16 files to Windows character set and back. Characters not included in Windows charset can be preserved.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-vim_ebcdic-159">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-vim_ebcdic_159-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            Vim
           </i>
           supports EBCDIC when compiled on a system that uses the EBCDIC character set.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-XEmacs_Unicode-160">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-XEmacs_Unicode_160-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           from version 21.5.29
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-gnuEmacsBidi-161">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-gnuEmacsBidi_161-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            GNU Emacs
           </i>
           <br/>
           <br/>
           (1) According to a comment in the source file where the bidi support is implemented (
           <a class="external free" href="http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/emacs.git/tree/src/bidi.c" rel="nofollow">
            http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/emacs.git/tree/src/bidi.c
           </a>
           accessed August 15, 2017), GNU Emacs doesn't fully conform to the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm (Unicode Annex #9, a.k.a. UAX #9) in the way it wraps the lines of a bidi paragraph: "we are violating paragraph 3.4 of UAX#9. which mandates that line breaking shall be done before reordering each screen line separately."
           <br/>
           <br/>
           (2) According to the online GNU Emacs manual (
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Bidirectional-Editing.html#Bidirectional-Editing" rel="nofollow">
            section 22.19 Bidirectional Editing
           </a>
           , accessed August 15, 2017), for the purpose of changing paragraph direction, "Paragraph boundaries are empty lines, i.e., lines consisting entirely of whitespace character". This contrasts with the otherwise ubiquitous convention of regarding the newline marker (LF on Unix derivatives, including macOS, and CR+LF on Windows) as the paragraph separator in plain text documents. However starting with version 26.0.50, the bidi paragraph separator can be customized.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-minedBidi-162">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-minedBidi_162-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-minedBidi_162-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            mined
           </i>
           : supports bidi in cooperation with bidi terminal (mlterm, mintty); also supports "poor man's bidi mode" (automatic visual text order right-to-left input) in normal terminal
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-NotepadppBidi-163">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-NotepadppBidi_163-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            Notepadpp
           </i>
           : Scintilla (Notepad++'s Engine) does not really support bidirectional editing.
           <a class="external free" href="https://sourceforge.net/p/scintilla/bugs/757/#01c9" rel="nofollow">
            https://sourceforge.net/p/scintilla/bugs/757/#01c9
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-164">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-164">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://superuser.com/questions/439440/did-mac-os-lion-switch-to-using-line-feeds-lf-n-for-line-breaks-instead-of" rel="nofollow">
             "Did Mac OS Lion switch to using line feeds (LF '\n') for line breaks instead of carriage returns (CR '\r')?"
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Did+Mac+OS+Lion+switch+to+using+line+feeds+%28LF+%27%5Cn%27%29+for+line+breaks+instead+of+carriage+returns+%28CR+%27%5Cr%27%29%3F&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsuperuser.com%2Fquestions%2F439440%2Fdid-mac-os-lion-switch-to-using-line-feeds-lf-n-for-line-breaks-instead-of&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AComparison+of+text+editors">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-gnuEmacsNewline-165">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-gnuEmacsNewline_165-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <i>
            GNU Emacs
           </i>
           : GNU Emacs doesn't regard the newline marker as a paragraph separator in bidi texts. See comment in the 'Right-to-left and bidirectional text' section.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-166">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-166">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://sourceforge.net/p/joe-editor/mercurial/ci/default/tree/docs/man.md#character-sets-and-utf-8" rel="nofollow">
             "JOE - Joe's Own Editor"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             JOE - Joe's own editor / Mercurial / [2e4f45] /docs/man.md
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              23 October
             </span>
             2015
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             character sets must use LF (0x0A) or CR-LF (0x0D - 0x0A) as line terminators […]. […] character sets which use CR terminated lines (MACs) will not yet work.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=JOE+-+Joe%26%2339%3Bs+own+editor+%2F+Mercurial+%2F+%5B2e4f45%5D+%2Fdocs%2Fman.md&amp;rft.atitle=JOE+-+Joe%27s+Own+Editor&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fsourceforge.net%2Fp%2Fjoe-editor%2Fmercurial%2Fci%2Fdefault%2Ftree%2Fdocs%2Fman.md%23character-sets-and-utf-8&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AComparison+of+text+editors">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>
      <!--

        <a accesskey="q" href="/wiki/Special:SpecialPages" title="A list of all special pages [q]">
